awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Sensor Science and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This renewal Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Maine (UMaine) focuses on sensor science and engineering research which is of high interest to the consumer, national defense, and homeland security, and reflects one of the top research strengths at UMaine. UMaine's sensor science and engineering research ranges from basic theoretical studies to the design, fabrication, and testing of prototype sensors for chemical and biological agents related to environmental contamination and terrorism; biomarkers for cancer detection, diagnosing nerve damage; high temperature sensors for monitoring and improving the efficiency of jet engines and turbines for power generation (coal or natural gas); and optical sensors for environmental monitoring. Other areas of research relate to using artificial intelligence to combine and analyze large data sets obtained from networked sensors, and exploring climate change through supercomputer visualizations. The program will provide state-of-the art, interdisciplinary research and problem solving opportunities for a diverse cohort of REU participants. Undergraduates will utilize their new knowledge to solve real-life research problems that impact society. Society will benefit as undergraduates, as a result of their research experiences, choose to continue in graduate school to excel in technologically and scientifically challenging careers that advance such areas as homeland security, food safety, transportation, communications, and medicine.

The REU program will offer a 10-week intensive summer research experience, for a total of 30 students, over a three year period. The program will include: 1) individual research projects with faculty research mentors utilizing specialized sensor science and engineering research facilities, 2) ethics training, 3) student meetings, 4) seminars, 5) field trips, 6) student presentations, and 7) career guidance, networking opportunities, and mentorship. A special effort will be made to recruit women and minorities and provide research experiences for students at non-PhD granting institutions. The REU participants will also interact with middle and high school teachers who were past REU and GK-12 participants to share their research experiences with middle and high school students, and provide a further role model for these students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site: Sensor Science and Engineering at the University of Maine Electrical and Computer Engineering Department hosted a total of 32 undergraduate researchers over the four year period of the grant. Of these students, 12 were women and five were minority students. 16 of the 32 students supported by the grant were from other institutions, meeting our recruitment goal for external recruitment. Through the REU Site and its administration, we have established recruitment networks among four-year colleges and universities, with a particular emphasis on HBCU and other minority serving institutions and institutions which do not grant Ph.D.s.

 

The REU fellows conducted STEM research projects on sensor materials and surfaces, sensor devices and sensing systems. The research projects covered a wide range of sensors and their applications. Examples include, but are not limited to, surface acoustic wave (SAW) sensors for high temperature and pressure sensors in power plant turbines for energy generation; biosensors for detection of neuropathy; radar-based sensors for remote monitoring of honey bee hives; passive sonar modules for monitoring the North Atlantic Right whale population in near lobstering areas and integration of multiple sensors for elderly care. Faculty in the Departments of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Chemistry, Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Physics and Astronomy, Chemical and Biomedical Engineering, and the School of Biology and Ecology at the University of Maine mentored the REU fellows.

 

All of the REU students made oral presentations at the end-of-program symposium. Additionally, 12 students presented their research at UMaine student symposium the following April, either in oral or poster presentation format. The REU research has resulted in two journal publications and three conference proceedings.

 

REU student research also contributed to the economic development of Maine. UMaine spun off two start-up companies, Neuright and Maine Biosensors, focusing on early neuropathy detection and bee hive monitoring, respectively. Both of these research projects spanned multiple years of this REU Site and the previous REU Site, and a total of 3 students from this REU Site participated in the early proof-of-concept research that lead to the founding of these companies. Two patents related to these technologies filed by UMaine were in part based on REU student research. Several other REU research involved collaborations with a Maine based small company, Environetix.

 

This REU Site has contributed to the growth of a highly skilled U.S. scientific and engineering workforce. The NSF-REU program has provided a valuable boost to the student's motivation toward both present and future graduate study, with at least 18 of the 32 students having started their graduate studies. The REU Site has given them the opportunity to apply advanced techniques in mathematics, physics and engineering in research and practical applications. It has also demonstrated the need for further course work to improve their skills.


Last Modified: 12/27/2023
Modified by: Nuri Emanetoglu
